Topology Ashan Jayamal 2024-02-13 Chapter 1 Topological Spaces 1.1 Topological Spaces Definition 1.1 A topology on a set \(X\) is a collection \(\mathcal{T}\) of subsets of \(X\) such that (T1) \(\phi\) and \(X\) are in \(\mathcal{T}\); (T2) Any union of subsets in \(\mathcal{T}\) is in \(\mathcal{T}\); (T3) The finite intersection of subsets in \(\mathcal{T}\) is in \(\mathcal{T}\). A set \(X\) with a topology \(\mathcal{T}\) is called a topological space. Denoted by \((X,\mathcal{T})\). An element of \(\mathcal{T}\) is called an open set. Example 1.1 Let \(X\) be a three-element set, \(X = \{a, b, c\}\) and \(\tau=\{X, \emptyset,\{a, b\}, \{b\}, \{b, c\}\}\). We can check T1,T2 and T3 conditions.
